channel.title: hypernormalized
channel.description: Reduction, systems, and the tension between order and entropy.

item.title: Order and Entropy
item.description:
My practice usually leans towards order. I look at Ikko Tanaka—radical reduction, geometric purity, the grid as a silent, invisible hand. It feels safe. It feels correct.

But then there is Tadanori Yokoo.

If Tanaka is the grid, Yokoo is the explosion that happens when the grid can no longer contain the pressure. His work is a “death statement” to the self—a psychedelic vomit of personal memory, cultural taboo, and pop art. It is chaotic, but it is not random.

This distinction matters for generative art. We often use Math.random() to introduce “life” or “chaos” into a system. But randomness is just white noise. It has no history. Yokoo’s chaos comes from memory—specific, loaded, heavy symbols crashing into each other.

To move beyond simple geometric exercises, the system needs more than just noise. It needs a memory bank. It needs to pull from a history, even if that history is fabricated. Chaos with context is narrative. Chaos without context is just static.

item.title: Absurdity as Structure
item.description:
Shigeo Fukuda said that design needs “30% dignity, 20% beauty, and 50% absurdity.”

That ratio feels correct for code, too. We often optimize for dignity (clean architecture, stability) or beauty (elegant output, smooth motion), but we forget the absurdity.

Absurdity isn’t just chaos. In Fukuda’s work—like the famous sculpture that casts a shadow of a motorcycle from a pile of junk—the absurdity is highly structured. It’s a trick that relies on precise alignment. It only works because the underlying logic is rigorous.

In generative systems, “absurdity” usually just means Math.random(). But true absurdity requires context. It requires a system that almost makes sense, but twists the logic just enough to break the viewer’s expectation. A grid that refuses to align. A loop that counts backward. A physics simulation where gravity works sideways, but only for blue objects.

Dignity provides the frame. Beauty provides the hook. But absurdity provides the reason to keep looking.

item.title: The Vital Element
item.description:
I’ve been looking at Kazumasa Nagai’s later work — the LIFE series specifically. There’s a severe shift that happens in his career, moving from strict geometric abstraction into something raw and hand-drawn.

What interests me is not just the stylistic change, but the motivation. He talks about striving to “deliver what I perceive from nature through my hands.” The work is about energy. “Strength to live.”

It’s a reminder that precision isn’t the only form of rigor. There is a kind of structural integrity in organic forms, too. In generative work, we often obsess over the grid, the perfect rule, the clean loop. Nagai’s creatures — these strange, etched animals — feel inevitable in a different way. They feel grown, not built.

I want to find that feeling in code. Not by simulating brush strokes (which always feels fake), but by finding algorithms that have that same nervous energy. Systems that wobble.

item.title: Nine Post Cards
item.description:
First study is up: Nine Post Cards.

It started with Yoshimura’s album of the same name — ambient piano pieces composed for a museum, meant to exist in the background of a space rather than the foreground of your attention. I wanted to see what that philosophy looks like as a generative visual system. Simple forms, slow movement, a narrow palette. Something that lives on the page without asking anything of you.

Every reload is a different composition. Same system, different moment. Like looking out the same window on different days.

item.title: Opening
item.description:
This is a space for working in the open.

I make things with code, mostly generative — systems that produce visual output through simple rules and structured randomness. The work lives somewhere between design and art, though I’m not precious about the distinction. What matters is the process: defining a system, watching it run, finding the moments where order starts to come apart.

The name hypernormalized comes from that tension. Systems that appear stable, coherent, inevitable — until you look at the seams. I’m interested in the seams.

Here you’ll find two kinds of things. The log is writing — notes on process, technique, ideas I’m working through. Studies are visual — generative sketches, usually built with p5.js, each one an experiment with a specific constraint or question.

Nothing here is finished. That’s the point. A studio is not a gallery.

item.title: Nine Post Cards
item.description:
In 1982, Hiroshi Yoshimura composed Music for Nine Post Cards for the Hara Museum of Contemporary Art in Tokyo. The pieces weren’t meant to be listened to so much as lived alongside — sound shaped by the architecture it inhabited, drifting like light across a white wall. The Japanese called this kankyō ongaku: environmental music. Art that accompanies rather than commands.

I keep coming back to this idea. Ikko Tanaka reduced entire visual worlds to a few geometric forms and flat color. Yoshimura reduced music to single piano notes and silence. Both understood that restraint isn’t absence — it’s attention.

This sketch tries to work in that space. Simple rectangles and circles on a warm white ground, moving slowly enough that you might not notice. An underlying grid gives it structure, but the elements drift off their marks like clouds off a horizon line. Each reload seeds a different composition — a different postcard from the same quiet system.

The palette is deliberately narrow. Warm grays, transparency, and a muted ochre that appears sparingly, the way a single sustained note might surface in one of Yoshimura’s pieces. Nothing demands your attention. It just runs.
